AStr.Run: It is now five <o'clock>.; It is five <a.m.>; It is five <p.m.>; It is noon <time>.; ten minutes <after> five.; <half> <past> five.; a <quarter> <to> five.; at ten <of> six.; a <quarter> <of> an hour.; in <half> an hour.; ten minutes <past> <the hour>.
Use this domain for words referring to planning the time of an event.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja tendo la kupanga saa la tukio fulani.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to planning the time of an event?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la kupanga saa la tukio fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: plan a time, set a date, schedule something, time something

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the time of an event?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja saa la tukio fulani?
(3) What words refer to a plan for the time of an event?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja mpango kuhusu saa la tukio fulani?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for machines that indicate what time it is.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayohusiana na mitambo inayoonyesha saa.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to machines for telling time?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja mitambo inayoonyesha saa?

ExampleWords.AUni: timepiece, watch, clock, alarm clock, digital watch, analog watch, electric clock, sundial, pendulum, hourglass
saa ya ukuta, saa ya mkononi

AStr.Run: Use the domains in this section for words that relate one time to another. Use this domain for words that indicate a temporal relation between situations.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja muda unohusiana na muda mwingine. Pamoja na hayo tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoonyesha mahusiano ya muda kati ya hali mbili au zaidi.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to one time in relation to another time?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida hutaja muda mmoja unaohusiana na muda mwingine, kwa jumla?

ExampleWords.AUni: relative to, in relation to, before or after

AStr.Run: When did it happen <relative to> his death?

Use this domain for words referring to temporal order or sequence--the order in which a group of events happen. Things and people may also be in order based on the order in which something happened or should happen to them.

Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja taratibu au ufuatano wa muda--yaani kundi la matukio yanatokea katika ufuatano fulani. Vitu na watu wanaweza kuwa katika ufuatano fulani kutokana na mambo kama mwaka waliooa au umri wao.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the order or sequence of a group of events?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja mfululizo au ufuatano wa kundi la matukio?

ExampleWords.AUni: order, sequence, cycle, pattern, rota, order of events,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a group of events that happen in order?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja kundi la matukio yanayotokea katika ufuatano?

ExampleWords.AUni: sequence, series, succession, chain, course, progression,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a group of things in a series?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja kundi la vitu katika ufuatano?
(4) What words describe a group of things that have been put in order?
(4) Maneno gani huelezea kundi la vitu ambavyo vimewekwa katika ufuatano fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: be in order, ordered, in sequence, be the right way round, in chronological order, chronological, consecutive, consecutively, successive, in succession, one after another, one after the other, (three years) running, sequential,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to doing things in order?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la kufanya mambo katika ufuatano fulani?
(6) What words refer to the particular order in which something comes?
(6) Maneno gani hutaja taratibu fulani ambayo katika yake wanakikundi hufuatana?

ExampleWords.AUni: ya kwanza, inayofuata, baada ya, ya mwisho, mwishoni

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe a group of things that have not been put in order?
(7) Maneno gani huelezea kundi la vitu ambavyo havijawekwa katika taratibu au ufuatano fulani?
(8) What words describe a group of things in the wrong order?
(8) Maneno gani hutaja kundi la vitu vilivyo katika ufuatano mbaya?

ExampleWords.AUni: be out of order, be in the wrong order, be the wrong way round, backwards,

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to something missing from a group of things in order?
(9) Maneno gani hutaja kitu ambacho kimeachwa katika taratibu au ufuatano wa vitu?

AStr.Run: Katika Kiswahili 'ufuatano' unaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai cha kitenzi kama vifuatavyo: "mtoto unaofuata" au "mwaka uliopita" Je, inawezekana katika lugha yako?

Question.AUni: (10) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with no overt marker.
(10) Katika Kiswahili 'ufuatano' unaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai cha kitenzi kama vifuatavyo: "mtoto unaofuata" au "mwaka uliopita" Ikiwa sahihi kufanya hivyo katika lugha yako, toa mifano?

AStr.Run: the first child; the second taxi; the next person (to speak); the last person (out the door)

Question.AUni: (11) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a 'be' clause with the 'Item' in the subject position.
(11) Katika Kiswahili 'ufuatano' unaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai kama vifuatavyo: "mtoto wa kwanza" au "mti wa pili." Ikiwa sahihi kufanya hivyo katika lugha yako, toa mifano?

AStr.Run: This child <was> first.

Question.AUni: (12) In English 'Order' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Item' marked by 'of'.

AStr.Run: the second <of> the winners
Use this domain for words related to a series--several things that happen one after another.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayohusiana na mfululizo--yaani mambo kadhaa yaliyotokea mfululizo.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to a series of things, events, numbers or people?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja mfululizo wa vitu, matukio, tarakimu, au watu?

ExampleWords.AUni: series, sequence, string of, succession of, stream, train of events, course of,

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe things in a series?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea vitu katika mfululizo?
(3) What words indicate that someone does things in a series?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba mtu anafanya mambo mfululizo?

ExampleWords.AUni: in succession, one after the other, one after another, straight, in a row, running, alternate

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to the place that something has in a series?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja sehemu ya kitu fulani katika mfululizo?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening first--to be before all other things in order or time.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja jambo linalotokea kwanza--yaani kuwa mbele ya vitu vingine vyote katika ufuatano au kabla ya mambo mengine yote katika muda.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is first in order or time?
(1) Maneno gani huelezea kitu cha mbele au cha kwanza katika ufuatano au muda?

ExampleWords.AUni: first, original, initial, earliest, inaugural, prime,

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate an event or action that is first?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha tukio au tendo lililo la kwanza?

ExampleWords.AUni: first (adv), first of all, beginning with, starting with,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something happened when you first saw something?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo lilitokea ulipokiona kitu fulani kwa mara ya kwanza?

ExampleWords.AUni: at first sight, at first glance

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that something is the first in a list of things that you will talk about?
(4) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo ni la kwanza katika orodha ya mambo unayotaka kuongea kuhusu hayo?

ExampleWords.AUni: firstly, first of all, to start with, to begin with, in the first place

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens or is done for the first time?
(5) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea au linafanyika kwa mara ya kwanza?
(6) What words refer to the first time someone does something?
(6) Maneno gani hutaja mara ya kwanza mtu anafanya jambo fulani?
(7) What words describe something that has never happened before?
(7) Maneno gani huelezea jambo ambalo halijawahi kutokea?
(8) What words refer to doing something that has never been done before?
(8) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la kufanya jambo ambalo halijawahi kufanyika?

ExampleWords.AUni: be the first to do something, show the way, lead the way, pioneer, break new ground,

Question.AUni: (9) What words refer to being the first person to do something in a situation instead of waiting for someone else?
(9) Maneno gani hutaja hali ya kuwa mtu wa kwanza kufanya jambo katika hali fulani badala ya kumsubiri mwingine afanye?

ExampleWords.AUni: make the first move, take the initiative,

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to the person who did something first?
(10) Maneno gani humtaja mtu ambaye alitangulia wote kufanya jambo fulani?
(11) What words refer to something that is the first of its kind?
(11) Maneno gani hutaja jambo lililo la kwanza la aina yake?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening next.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja jambo lijalo ambalo litatokea.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that an event happens next?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba tukio fulani linakuja kutokea (baada ya tukio la sasa hivi)?

ExampleWords.AUni: next, right afterwards, the day after, then,

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens next?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea jambo linalofuata (yaani baada ya tukio la sasa hivi)?
(3) What words refer to an event happening next after another event?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la tukio fulani kutokea baada ya tukio lingine?

ExampleWords.AUni: follow, come next, be after, be next, succeed, come after, go after, go next, ensue,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something happening last--to happen after all other things in a sequence, or to be the last person or thing in a sequence.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja jambo la mwisho kutokea--yaani kutokea baada ya mambo yote mengine katika ufuatano fulani, au hali ya kuwa mtu au kitu cha mwisho katika ufuatano.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that an event happens last?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba tukio fulani ni la mwisho kutokea?
(2) What words describe something that happens last?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea jambo ambalo ni la mwisho kutokea?
(3) What words refer to an event happening last?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la tukio fulani kuwa la mwisho kutokea?

ExampleWords.AUni: come last, end with, finish with,

Question.AUni: (4) What words indicate that a person or thing is the last in a list or line or group?
(4) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba mtu au kitu ni cha mwisho katika orodha, safu, au kundi?

ExampleWords.AUni: be last, come last, finish last, bring up the rear, straggler, be the last straw,

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something is next to the last?
(5) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba kitu ni cha pili kutoka mwisho?

ExampleWords.AUni: next to the last, the last but one, penultimate,

Question.AUni: (6) What words indicate that something is the last before now?
(6) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba kitu ni cha mwisho kabla ya sasa?
(7) What words do people use to indicate the last thing in a list of things they are talking about?
(7) Watu hutumia maneno gani kuonyesha kitu cha mwisho katika orodha ya vitu ambavyo wanaviongelea?

ExampleWords.AUni: lastly, finally, last but not least,

Question.AUni: (8) What words refer to the last thing?
(8) Maneno gani hutaja jambo la mwisho?
(9) What words refer to the last part of something?
(9) Maneno gani hutaja sehemu ya mwisho ya kitu au jambo fulani?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to something that happens regularly.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja jambo linalotokea kwa kawaida.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens regularly?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea kwa kawaida?

ExampleWords.AUni: regular, regularly, at regular intervals, every day, daily, be punctuated by, with great regularity, routine, like clockwork

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens sometimes but not regularly?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba pengine jambo linatokea, lakini halitokei kwa kawaida?

ExampleWords.AUni: intermittently, intermittent, on and off, off and on, in fits and starts, sporadic,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something does not happen regularly?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo halitokei kwa kawaida?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to alternating--when several things happen one after another in a repeated pattern.

Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanyohusiana na tendo la kupokezana--yaani wakati mambo kadhaa yanapotokea mfululizo katika ufuatano unaorudiarudia (la kwanza linatokea, halafu la pili, halafu la kwanza tena, halafu la pili tena, n.k.)

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to things alternating?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja mambo yakipokezana?
(2) What words describe things that alternate?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea mambo ambayo yanapokezana?
(3) What words indicate that two things alternate?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba mambo mawili yanapokezana?
(4) What words refer to two or more people doing something in alternate turns?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja watu wawili au zaidi wakifanya jambo kwa zamu zinazopokezana?

ExampleWords.AUni: alternate, take turns, take it in turns, share, spell each other, go back and forth,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening before another.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja tukio moja likitokea kabla ya lingine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens before a particular event?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea kabla ya tukio fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: before (conj), prior to, on the eve of, pre-,

AStr.Run: John took a bath <before> eating dinner.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens before now or before a particular time?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea kabla ya sasa au kabla ya saa fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: before (adv), earlier, formerly, previously, ago, already,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that someone does something before a particular event?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba mtu anafanya jambo kabla ya tukio fulani?
(4) What words indicate that something must be done before a particular time?
(4) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba ni lazima jambo lifanyike kabla ya saa fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: before, by, not later than, at the latest,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to something that happened before?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja jambo ambalo limewahi kutokea?

ExampleWords.AUni: antecedent, precedent, precedence, the one before,

Question.AUni: (6) What words describe something that happened before?
(6) Maneno gani huelezea jambo ambalo limewahi kutokea?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous, old, last (adj), earlier, former, prior, preceding, recent, preliminary,

Question.AUni: (7) What words describe a time that comes before another one?
(7) Maneno gani huelezea muda unaotangulia mwingine?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous (day), last (night), the (week) before, the preceding (year)

Question.AUni: (8) What words indicate that something comes before another in a series?
(8) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea kabla ya lingine katika mfululizo?

ExampleWords.AUni: before, in front of, ahead of,

Question.AUni: (9) What words describe something that comes before another in a series?
(9) Maneno gani huelezea jambo linalotokea kabla ya lingine katika mfululizo?

ExampleWords.AUni: previous, preceding, earlier, the one before,

Question.AUni: (10) What words refer to something happening before something else?
(10) Maneno gani hutaja jambo linalotokea kabla ya lingine?

ExampleWords.AUni: come before, precede, predate, lead up to, come first, be before, be a prelude to, anticipate, antedate,

Question.AUni: (11) What words refer to coming before something else in a series?
(11) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la jambo moja kutangulia lingine katika mfululizo?
(12) What words refer to doing something before someone else does it?
(12) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la kufanya jambo kabla mwingine hajalifanya?

ExampleWords.AUni: do something first, be first, beat someone to it, ahead of, be ahead of your time,

Question.AUni: (13) What words refer to a person or thing that existed before another?
(13) Maneno gani humtaja mtu au kitu ambacho kilikuwepo kabla ya kingine?
(14) What words describe something that has been mentioned before?
(14) Maneno gani huelezea jambo lililotajwa kabla ya sasa?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to one event happening after another.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja tukio moja likitokea baada ya lingine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens after a particular time or event?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea baada ya tukio au saa fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: after, afterward, afterwards, later, later on, subsequently, after that, beyond that, hence,

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens after a certain period of time?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea baada ya kipindi fulani cha muda?
(3) What words describe something that comes after something else?
(3) Maneno gani huelezea jambo linalofuata jambo lingine?

ExampleWords.AUni: next, following, later, subsequent, succeeding, ensuing, after, future, consequent, latter,

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something happening after something else?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la jambo moja kutokea baada ya lingine?

ExampleWords.AUni: follow, come after, ensue, follow-up, be after,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the events that happen after an event?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja matukio yanayotokea baada ya tukio fulani?
(6) What words refer to a person who takes a job or position after someone else?
(6) Maneno gani humtaja mtu anayechukua kazi fulani baada ya mtu mwingine kuiacha?
(7) What words refer to a book or film that comes after another one?
(7) Maneno gani hutaja kitabu au filamu inayofuata nyingine?
(8) What words indicate that something comes after another in a series?
(8) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo moja linatokea baada ya lingine katika mfululizo?
(9) What words indicate that something will not be done now, but later?
(9) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo halitafanyika sasa, lakini litafanyika baadaye?

ExampleWords.AUni: later, it can wait, it will wait,

Question.AUni: (10) What words are used to link events when telling a story?
(10) Maneno gani hutumika katika kuunga matukio wakati wa kusimulia hadithi?

ExampleWords.AUni: and, and then, then, having...-en, after, thereafter, thereon, thereupon, whereupon, upon,

AStr.Run: John took a bath, <and> ate a big dinner.; John took a bath, <and then> ate a big dinner.; <Having> tak<en> a bath, John ate a big dinner.; <After> taking a bath, John ate a big dinner.
Use this domain for words referring to two things happening at the same time.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja matukio mawili yakitokea pamoja (au muda huohuo).

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that two things happen at the same time?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba mambo mawili yanatokea pamoja (au muda huohuo)?

ExampleWords.AUni: at the same time, together, at one time, at once, simultaneously, at the same instant, in concert, in unison,

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happens at the same time as something else?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linatokea pamoja na jambo lingine (yaani yanatokea muda huohuo)?

ExampleWords.AUni: at the same time as, meanwhile, while, as, -ing, simultaneity, concurrently, coincident,

AStr.Run: John went out to the garden, carry<ing> his hoe and shovel.; Mary bought food, <while> John got gas for the car.

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to two things happening at the same time?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja mambo mawili yakitokea pamoja (au muda huohuo)?
(4) What words refer to arranging two events so that they happen at the same time?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja tendo la kupanga matukio mawili ili yatokee pamoja (au muda huohuo)?
(5) What words describe things that happen at the same time?
(5) Maneno gani huelezea mambo yanayotokea pamoja (au muda huohuo)?

ExampleWords.AUni: simultaneous, synchronized, parallel, synchronous, contemporaneous, concurrent,

Question.AUni: (6) What words refer to two people that lived at the same time?
(6) Maneno gani huwataja watu wawili walioishi katika kipindi kilekile?

ExampleWords.AUni: contemporary, be a contemporary of someone, be contemporaries

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened during some time period, or that something happened while something else was happening.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoonyesha kwamba jambo lilitokea wakati wa kipindi fulani, au kwamba jambo lilitokea wakati jambo lingine lilitokea.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happened during some time period?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo lilitokea wakati wa kipindi fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: during, in, in the course of, during the course of, through, throughout, over, by day, by night, during the middle of, in the interim, within

AStr.Run: It rained <during> the night.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something happened during the time when something else was happening?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo lilitokea wakati jambo lingine lilitokea?

AStr.Run: I decided to eat something <while> I waited for the rain to stop.
Use this domain for words referring to the right time to do something.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayotaja muda mwafaka wa kufanya jambo fulani.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the right time to do something?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja muda mwafaka wa kufanya jambo fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: the right time, a good time, be the time,

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something happening at the right time?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea jambo likitokea katika muda mwafaka?

ExampleWords.AUni: timely, opportune, well-timed, come at the right time,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a person's ability to choose the right time to do something?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja uwezo wa mtu kuchagua muda mwafaka wa kufanya jambo fulani?
(4) What words refer to the wrong time to do something?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja muda usio mwafaka wa kufanya jambo fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: the wrong time, a bad time, not a good time, be no time, not be the time,

Question.AUni: (5) What words describe something happening at the wrong time?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja jambo linalotokea katika muda usio mwafaka?

ExampleWords.AUni: badly-timed, ill-timed, come at the wrong time, at a bad time, inopportune,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate that something happens early--before the expected time, before the usual time, or before the time that was agreed on. Some words may include the idea that it is good that the event happened early. Other words may include the idea that it is bad that the event happened early.

Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanyoonyesha kwamba jambo linawahi--yaani linatokea kabla ya muda unaotarajiwa, kabla ya muda wa kawaida, au kabla ya muda uliokubalika. Maneno mengi yanaonyesha wazo la kwamba ni nzuri kwamba tukio liliwahi. Maneno mengine yanaonyesha wazo la kwamba ni vibaya kwamba tukio liliwahi.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something happens early?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo liliwahi au lilitokea mapema?

ExampleWords.AUni: early (adv), ahead of time, ahead of schedule, in good time,

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that happens early?
(2) Maneno gani huelezea jambo linalowahi au linalotokea mapema?
(3) What words refer to something happening early?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja jambo linalowahi au linalotokea mapema?
(4) What words indicate that something happens too early?
(4) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo linawahi sana au linatokea mapema sana?

ExampleWords.AUni: too early, too soon, untimely, premature, prematurely, jump the gun,

Question.AUni: (5) What words indicate that something happens early in the morning?

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something contains something?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba kitu fulani kina kitu fulani ndani yake?
(2) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb 'contain' with the 'Container' in the subject position and the 'Content' in the object position.

(2) Katika baadhi ya lugha dhana ya 'Uchombo' inaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kishazi kikitumia kitenzi 'Kuchomba' ('Kuchukua') kikiwa na 'Chombo' kuwa mtendaji na 'Yaliyomo' kuwa mtendwa. Ebu, angalia kishazi kilichopo hapo chini. Je, ni sahihi ikifanyikiwa hivyo katika lugha yako? Ikiwa sahihi, naomba utoe mfano wa mfumo huo.

AStr.Run: The cup <contained> milk.
Kikombe kinachukua maziwa.

Question.AUni: (3) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb with the 'Container' in the subject position, the 'Content' in the object position, and the 'Container' in a preposition phrase marked by 'in'.

(3) Katika baadhi ya lugha dhana ya 'Uchombo' inaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kishazi kikitumia kitenzi pamoja na 'Chombo' ikiwa mtendaji, 'Yaliyomo' ikiwa mtendwa, na 'Chombo' kuwepo pia katika kirai cha kihusishi, huwa kinatumia 'ndani'. Ebu, angalia kishazi kilichopo hapo chini. Je, ni sahihi ikifanyikiwa hivyo katika lugha yako? Ikiwa sahihi, naomba utoe mfano wa mfumo huo.

AStr.Run: The cup <has> milk <in it>.
Kikombe kina maziwa ndani yake.

Question.AUni: (4) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.

(4) Katika baadhi ya lugha dhana ya 'Uchombo' inaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai cha nomino kikiwa na 'Chombo' kuwa nomino kuu na 'Yaliyomo' ikitanguliwa na "cha, ya, vya, wa, n.k.". Ebu, angalia kirai kilichopo hapo chini. Je, ni sahihi ikifanyikiwa hivyo katika lugha yako? Ikiwa sahihi, naomba utoe mfano wa mfumo huo.

AStr.Run: a cup <of> milk
kikombe cha maziwa

Question.AUni: (5) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.

(5) Katika baadhi ya lugha dhana ya 'Uchombo' inaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai cha nomino kikiwa na neno 'chombo' kuwa nomino kuu na 'Yaliyomo' ikitanguliwa na "cha, ya, vya, wa, n.k.". Ebu, angalia kirai kilichopo hapo chini. Je, ni sahihi ikifanyikiwa hivyo katika lugha yako? Ikiwa sahihi, naomba utoe mfano wa mfumo huo.

AStr.Run: the <container> <of> milk
chombo cha maziwa

Question.AUni: (6) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'contents' as the head and the 'Container' marked by 'of'.

(6) Katika baadhi ya lugha dhana ya 'Uchombo' inaweza kuonyeshwa kwa kutumia kirai cha nomino kikiwa ne neno 'yaliyomo' kuwa nomino kuu na 'Chombo' ikitanguliwa na "cha, ya, vya, wa, n.k.". AStr.Run: Use this domain for technical linguistic terms that refer to grammatical words and constructions. Most languages have few if any words in this domain.

ExampleWords.AUni: noun, verb, adjective, adverb, conjunction, preposition, particle, article, word, participle, infinitive, part of speech, compound, derivative

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to types of grammatical constructions?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja aina za uundaji wa kisarufi?

ExampleWords.AUni: root, stem, affix, prefix, suffix, ending, morpheme,

Question.AUni: (5) What words are used to talk about grammar?
(5) Maneno gani hutumika kwa kuongelea sarufi?

ExampleWords.AUni: inflect, inflection, case, decline, declension, conjugate, conjugation, parse, paradigm, rule, singular, plural

Question.AUni: (6) What words are used to talk about the sounds of a language?
(6) Maneno gani hutumika kwa kuongelea sauti za lugha?

AStr.Run: Use the following section for words that don't belong in any other domain because they are so general in meaning that you can use them to talk about any topic. Use this domain for general and indefinite words that can be used in the place of any word. Some languages have a general word that can replace a noun or a verb. For instance some Philippine languages use the word 'kwan' in this way. Colloquial German can use the word 'dings' as a noun or verb. Often these words are used when you can't remember the particular word you are trying to think of. In English we use the word 'blank' when we don't want to say a word, for instance when we are testing someone and want them to say the word.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoweza kuchukua nafasi ya neno lolote. Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno ya kawaida na maneno yasiyoweza kuingizwa katika maeneo ya maana mengine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words can be used in the place of any word?
(1) Maneno gani huweza kuchukua nafasi ya neno lolote?

ExampleWords.AUni: blank, ... (ellipsis), you know what I mean

AStr.Run: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'be' may be used to identify something, describe something, and many other ideas.

Lugha nyingi zina maneno ya kawaida yanayoonyesha hali fulani. Maneno ya kawaida haya yanaweza kutumika kwa kumaanisha mambo mengi maalumu. K.m., katika Kiswahili neno "ni" inaweza kutimika kwa kuelezea kitu, kutaja kitu, na mambo mengine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to something being something?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja kitu kikiwa jambo fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: be, represent, amount to, form, make, constitute

AStr.Run: Your idea <is> good.
Wazo lako <ni> nzuri

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something is being identified?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo fulani linatajiwa?

AStr.Run: John <is> our new leader.; This <is> a pine tree.
Yohana <ni> kiongozi wetu.; Huu <ni> mgomba.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that a group of things is something?
(3) Maneno gani huonyehsa kwamba kundi la vitu ni jambo fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: make up, form, constitute, add up to,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that something exists.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoonyesha kwamba kitu fulani kipo -- yaani, siyo cha fikra, ni cha kweli.

(1) Maneno gani hutumika kuonyesha kwamba jambo fulani lipo?

ExampleWords.AUni: exist, existence, there is, there exists, there lives, be, be found, occur, be in existence, be in operation, real,

AStr.Run: <There is> a man....; <There was> a man....; <There exists> evidence....; Evidence <exists>....; God <exists>.; I think, therefore I <am>.; Once upon a time <there lived> a man....
<Yupo> mtu fulani...; <Alikuwepo> mtu fulani...; Ushahidi <upo>...; Mungu <yuko hai>.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something starting to exist?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja kitu kikianza kuwepo?

ExampleWords.AUni: appear, arise, coalesce, come into being, come into existence, come to be, develop, emerge, form, materialize, spring up, take shape

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to continuing to exist?

ExampleWords.AUni: remain, persist, persistence, survive, survival, survivor,

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something ceasing to exist?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja kitu kikiisha kuwepo?

ExampleWords.AUni: become extinct, extinction, die out, disappear, vanish, cease to exist, disappearance, disintegrate, disintegration, fade, loss,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to not existing?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja hali ya kutokuwepo -- yaani, labda ilikuwepo zamani lakini siyo sasa, au haijawahi kuwepo?

ExampleWords.AUni: non-existent, extinct, there's no, there's no such thing,

AStr.Run: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of change of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'become' may be used to a change in identity, a change in characteristic, a change in nature, and many other ideas.

Lugha nyingi zina maneno ya kawaida yanayoonyesha kwamba mabadiliko ya hali fulani yametokea. Maneno haya huweza kutumika yakiwa na maana nyingi maalumu. K.m., katika Kiswahili neno 'kuwa' linaweza kutumika kwa kutaja mabadiliko ya nafsi au sura, mabadiliko ya sifa fulani, mabadiliko ya asili, na mambo mengi mengine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate a change of state?
(1) Maneno gani hutumika kuonyehsa mabadiliko ya hali?

ExampleWords.AUni: become (characteristic), change, come to be, turn, get, develop, grow into, turn into, change into, become different, evolve

AStr.Run: John <became> president last year.; The sky <turned> red as the sun set.; After a long illness, John finally <got> better.
Yohana <alianza kuwa> rais mwaka uliopita.

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used of causing or producing a state?
(2) Maneno gani hutumika kwa kusababisha mabadiliko ya hali?

ExampleWords.AUni: produce, cause to be, make to be, make, make into, result in, bring upon, bring about

AStr.Run: He <made> me angry.
Alini<sababisha> nikasirike.

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used of attaining a state?
(3) Maneno gani hutumika kwa kupata kuwa hali fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: come to be, attain, achieve, reach

AStr.Run: He <reached> the age of 100.
Ali<fika> umri wa miaka 100.

Many languages have several general words that are used to indicate a variety of relationships between two things. There are three such words in English: "have," "of," and the possessive suffix "-'s." The basic meaning of these words in English is 'to own', but they can mean many other things too. For instance they can mean that I am related to someone (I have a brother), something has a part (birds have wings), and many other ideas. There is also a set of pronouns in English that are like nouns ending in -'s (my/mine, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, our/ours, their/theirs, whose). Use this domain for these general words.
Lugha nyingi zina maneno mengi ya kawaida yanayotumika kuonyesha mahusiano ya aina mbalimbali baina ya vitu viwili. Baadhi ya maneno haya katika Kiswahili ni "kuwa na", na "cha, ya, vya, wa n.k.".

Question.AUni: (1) What general words relate two nouns?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida huhusisha nomino mbili?

AStr.Run: Own: John <has> a house (to sell), the house <of> John, John<'s> house, hi<s> house, who<se> house (is this?), the house is hi<s>; Kinship: John <has> a brother, the brother <of> John, John<'s>brother, hi<s> brother; Relationship: John <has> a friend, the friend <of> John, John<'s> friend, a friend of hi<s>; Member: The school <has> (a hundred) students, the students <of> the school, the school<'s> students; Part: Trees <have> leaves, the leaves <of> the tree, the tree<'s> leaves, it<s> leaves; Name: John <has> three names, the three names <of> John, John<'s> three names, hi<s> names; Know: John <has> the answer, John<'s> answer, hi<s> answer; Hold: John <has> the key (in his pocket), John<'s> key, hi<s> key; Feel: John <has> anger, the anger <of> John, John's anger, hi<s> anger; Sickness: John <has> cancer, John<'s> cancer, hi<s> cancer; Located on: The yard <has> a fence, the yard<'s> fence; Be pictured in: the photo <of> John, John<'s> photo, hi<s> photo; Quality: John <has> status, the status <of> John, John<'s> status, hi<s> status; Use: The secretary <has> a computer, the computer <of> the secretary, the secretary<'s> computer, the computer is her<s>; Event: the arrival <of> John, John<'s> arrival, hi<s> arrival
Yohana <ana> majina matatu.; Majina matatu <ya> Yohana

Attributes often belong to a class of attributes (shape = straight, curved) or to a scale (length = long, short). The class or scale can sometimes be included in the expression, but does not mark the proposition itself. (The towel <feels> damp. The box <weighs> five kilos.)
Uangamaji wa neno husababisha kujua umiliki au chanzo lake.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate an attribute of something?
(1) Maneno gani hutumika kuonyesha uangamaji wa kitu fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: found to be, discover to be, turn out to be, be in many ways

AStr.Run: <be> characteristic, state; <have> condition; <bear> characteristic; <be in a state of> characteristic; The dirt <is> red.; The towel <is> damp.; This man <is> important.; This man <has> an important status.; The towel<'s> dampness.; The dampness <of> the towel.; The damp state <of> this towel.
<kuwa na> sifa fulani; udongo <ni> mwekundu; Mtu huyu <ni> muhimu; uchepechepe <wa> kitambaa; hali ya uchepechepe <ya> kitambaa hiki

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate a point on a scale?
(2) Maneno gani huonyesha kimefikapo kwenye skeli kwa kitu fulani?

AStr.Run: The box <weighs> five kilos.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate an evaluation of something?
(3) Maneno gani huonyesha tathmini ya kitu fulani?

AStr.Run: That woman <is> beautiful.
Mwanamke huyu <ni> mzuri.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate event propositions. Event propositions are similar in that they are normally expressed by a subject and a verb, possibly including an object, indirect object, or complement clause. However there are multiple ways in which a language can express an event, such as a passive construction, noun phrase, or subordinate clause. In addition each event type is different in its primary cases, and in the ways those cases are marked. Each event type has subtypes, such as intransitive, transitive, and bitransitive verbs. A great deal of research is needed in order to identify all the variations. Ultimately every verb must be investigated to determine how it behaves in each syntactic construction and how its case relations are marked. No two verbs are entirely alike.

Tumia eneo hili kwa vihusishi, yaani aina ya maneno ambayo huonyesha uhusiano baina ya kirai (au kipashio) kimoja na kirai kingine. Huwa vihusishi hivi vinatumia kiima na kitenzi, na labda aina za maneno mengine.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate an event?
(1) Maneno gani huonyesha tukio lililo sehemu kuu ya sentensi?

AStr.Run: A bark<ing> dog (kept me awake last night).; The dog<'s> bark<ing> (woke me up).; The bark<ing> <of> a dog (woke me up).; (John told me) <to> wake him up at 6 a.m.; I want <to> do something.; He started do<ing> something.
Kubweka <kwa> mbwa (kuliniamsha usiku).; Ninataka <ku>fanya jambo fulani.;
Use this domain for general words referring to things.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno ya kawaida yanayohusiana na vitu.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to a thing?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida hutaja kitu?

ExampleWords.AUni: thing, something, article, artifact, entity, item, object, wares,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a group of things of different types?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja kundi la vitu vya aina mbalimbali?

ExampleWords.AUni: things, oddments, paraphernalia, stuff, odds and ends, bits and pieces, knick-knacks,

Question.AUni: (3) What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called?
(3) Maneno gani hutumika kutaja kitu ambacho umesahau kinaitwaje?

ExampleWords.AUni: what's its name, thingy, thingamajig, whatchamacallit, whatsit, such and such

Question.AUni: (4) What words are used to end a list of things to indicate that there are more things in the list?
(4) Maneno gani hutumika kwa mwisho wa orodha ili kuonyesha kwamba bado vingine vipo lakini havijatajwa?

ExampleWords.AUni: et cetera, etc., and what not, and so forth, and the like, and on and on, ... [ellipsis]

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words describing something that is physical--that you can touch and see, and for words describing something that is non-physical--that you cannot touch or see.

Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoelezea kitu kilicho cha maumbile -- yaani, unachoweza kukiona na kukigusa. Pia tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayoelezea kitu kilicho cha kiroho -- yaani, huwezi kukiona wala kukigusa.

Question.AUni: (1) What words describe something that is physical?
(1) Maneno gani huelezea kitu kilicho cha maumbili?

ExampleWords.AUni: animal nature, biological, bodily, concrete, corporal, corporeal, earthly, earthy, fleshly, incarnate, inferior, matter, material, materialistic, mundane, natural, objective, physical, seen, sensible, sensual, tangible, temporal, unspiritual, worldly

AStr.Run: A ghost cannot take <physical> form.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to something that is physical?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja kitu kilicho cha maumbili?
(3) What words describe something that is non-physical?
(3) Maneno gani huelezea kitu kilicho cha kiroho?

ExampleWords.AUni: disembodied, extramundane, extrasensory, immaterial, impalpable, incorporeal, instinctive, intangible, intellectual, libidinal, life, mental, metaphysical, nonphysical, nonmaterial, numinous, otherworldly, preternatural, psychic, psychological, rational, reasoning, spiritual, spiritualist, subjective, supernatural, transcendent, transcendental, unbodied, unearthly, unseen, unworldly,

AStr.Run: Thoughts and ideas belong to the <spiritual> realm.
Mawazo na dhana ziko kwenye dunia ya <kiroho>.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something that is non-physical?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja kitu kilicho cha kiroho?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a situation--a particular time and place, and the things that are true about it.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa maneno yanayohusiana na hali -- yaani, muda na sehemu maalumu, na matukio yaliyohusiana na muda na sehemu ile.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the general situation that exists in a place?
(1) Maneno gani hutaja hali iliyopo kwa jumla katika sehemu fulani ?

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, things, conditions, state of affairs, set-up, context,

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a situation that affects what can happen or what people can do?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja hali inayoathiri matukio yanayoweza kutoka au watu wanavyoweza kufanya?

ExampleWords.AUni: situation, circumstances, environment, climate, conditions, the lay of the land, which way the wind blows, scenario,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to a situation that exists at some time during a larger event or process?
(3) Maneno gani hutaja hali iliyopo wakati wa kipindi fulani cha tukio kubwa au utaratibu fulani?
(4) What words refer to the true situation rather than the situation that people think exists?
(4) Maneno gani hutaja hali iliyopo kweli badala ya hali ambayo watu wanafikiri ipo?

ExampleWords.AUni: the picture, the score, what's going on,

Question.AUni: (5) What words refer to the situation a person is in?
(5) Maneno gani hutaja hali iliyopo kwa mtu fulani?
(6) What words indicate that something must happen or cannot happen because of the situation?
(6) Maneno gani huonyesha kwamba jambo fulani linapaswa kutokea au haliweza kutokea kwa sababu ya hali fulani?

ExampleWords.AUni: under the circumstances, in the circumstances, given the circumstances, given the situation, as it is, as things stand, force of circumstances, the way things are,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general adjectives that can replace or stand for a specific adjective.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa vivumishi vya kawaida vinavyoweza kuwakilisha au kuchukua nafasi ya kivumishi maalumu.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words can replace an adjective?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida huchukua nafasi ya kivumishi, kwa jumla?

ExampleWords.AUni: such, that kind of, that sort of,

AStr.Run: We all admire <such> a man. (a generous man); We all admire <that kind of> a man.; We all admire <that sort of> a man.

Question.AUni: (2) What question words ask for an adjective in the answer?
(2) Maneno ya maswali yapi huomba kivumishi kiwepo katika jibu?

ExampleWords.AUni: what kind of, what sort of,

AStr.Run: <What kind of> a man is he? (a good man); <What sort of> man is he?

Question.AUni: (3) What question words ask for an ad-adjective in the answer?
(3) Maneno ya maswali yapi huomba kivumishi cha kiasi kiwepo katika jibu?

AStr.Run: <How> big a box is it? (very big)
Use this domain for general adverbs that can replace or stand for other adverbs.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa vielezi vya kawaida vinavyoweza kuwakilisha au kuchukua nafasi ya vielezi vingine.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words can replace an adverb?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida huchukua nafasi ya kielezi, kwa jumla?

ExampleWords.AUni: thus, thusly, so, how, like this, this way, in that way, in this manner

AStr.Run: We would like you to do it <thus>.; I'll show you <how> I want it.

This domain is for organization purposes and should not be used for any words. Use the domains in this section for words that belong to a particular part of speech. It is best not to use these domains, since they are based on grammar and not meaning. But if you have a small group of words that belong to a part of speech and you want to list them all, you can use these domains. You can also classify words in this section if you don't know what they mean yet.
Eneo la maana hili ni la kupangia tu na haliomba maneno.

Use this domain to list all adjectives. If there are many adjectives in your language, you should not try to list them all here. If you want to find all the adjectives, most dictionary programs can sort your dictionary by part of speech. However if your language only has a few adjectives, you can list them all in this domain. In the book, "Where Have All the Adjectives Gone?" R. M. W. Dixon [Dixon, R. M. W. 1982. Where have all the adjectives gone? Berlin: Mouton.] identifies seven universal semantic types that are often expressed by adjectives. They are: Age (new, young, old), Dimension (big, little, long, short, wide, narrow, thick, fat, thin), Value (good, bad, proper, perfect, excellent, fine, delicious, atrocious, poor), Color (black, white, red), Human propensity (jealous, happy, kind, clever, generous, cruel, rude, proud, wicked), Physical property (hard, soft, heavy, light, rough, smooth, hot, cold, sweet, sour), Speed (fast, slow). Words in the Human propensity class may be nouns. Words in the Physical property and Speed classes may be verbs.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa kuorodhesha vihusishi -- yaani, maneno yanayoelezea mtu, kitu au sehemu fulani na katika lugha za Kibantu huwa yanapatana na nomino ile.

Question.AUni: (1) What are the adjectives in your language?
(1) Vihusishi vilivyopo katika lugha yako ni vipi?

ExampleWords.AUni: young, big, good, black, kind, hot, fast,

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all adverbs. If there are many adverbs in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa kuorodhesha vielezi vyote -- yaani, maneno yanayoelezea tendo.

Question.AUni: (1) What adverbs are in your language?
(1) Vielezi vilivyopo katika lugha yako ni vipi?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for the personal pronouns, including independent, subject, object, and possessive pronouns. It is best to collect all the pronouns in a chart. This way you are more certain of collecting them all and seeing how they are related to each other. A language may have more sets and more distinctions than English does, or it may have less. For instance some languages have a pronoun 'we' which includes the hearer, and another pronoun 'we' which excludes the hearer. Other languages have an indefinite pronoun that means something like the English word 'someone'. Many languages do not have the masculine (he), feminine (she), and neuter (it) distinctions that English has. It is necessary to determine the sets and functions of the pronouns for each language.
Tumia eneo la maana hili kwa viwakilishi, yaani maneno yatumiwayo badala ya nomino.

Question.AUni: (1) What general words refer to the class of pronouns?
(1) Maneno gani ya kawaida hutaja aina ya viwakilishi?
(2) What pronouns refer to the speaker?
(2) Viwakilishi vipi hutaja anayeongea?
(3) What pronouns refer to the speaker and those associated with the speaker?
(3) Viwakilishi vipi hutaja anayeongea na waliopo naye?
(4) What pronouns refer to the audience?
(4) Viwakilishi vipi hutaja wasikilizaji?
(5) What pronouns refer to the people or things being spoken about?
(5) Viwakilishi vipi hutaja watu au vitu vinavyoongelewa?

ExampleWords.AUni: he, him, his, she, her, hers, it, its, they, them, their, theirs
yeye, kile, wao, vile, ile, zile n.k.

Question.AUni: (6) What pronouns are used for the subject of a sentence?
(6) Viwakilishi vipi hutumika kwa kiima cha sentensi?

ExampleWords.AUni: I, you, he, she, it, we, you, they
mimi, wewe, yeye, sisi, ninyi, wao, hii, hiki, hivi, hizi n.k.

AStr.Run: <I> went to town.

Question.AUni: (7) What pronouns are used for the object of a sentence?

ExampleWords.AUni: me, you, him, her, it, us, you, them

AStr.Run: John hit <me>.

Question.AUni: (8) What pronouns are used in a possessive phrase?

ExampleWords.AUni: my, your, his, her, its, our, your, their

AStr.Run: This is <my> house.

Question.AUni: (9) What pronouns are used in a possessive clause?

ExampleWords.AUni: mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, yours, theirs

AStr.Run: That house is <mine>.

Question.AUni: (10) What pronouns are used to emphasize the people or things being spoken about, especially when you are emphasizing that one person does something and not someone else?

ExampleWords.AUni: as for me (I), as for you (you), as for him (he), as for us (we), as for them (they)

AStr.Run: He <himself> admits he is guilty.; I did it <myself> without any help.; You can do what you want. <As for me>, I'm not going.
Use this domain for pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. These pronouns should be added to the chart of personal pronouns.
Tumia eneo hili kwa viwakilishi jirejee, yaani kwa viwakilishi ambavyo hurejea kwenye kiima cha sentensi.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns express reflexive reference?

ExampleWords.AUni: self, myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves, oneself

AStr.Run: I cut <myself>.

Question.AUni: (2) What pronouns express reciprocal reference?

AStr.Run: They hit <each other>.; We should help <one another>.

Use this domain for pronouns that do not refer to a definite person or thing, but can refer to anyone or anything. Some languages will not have all the sets of pronouns described below. Add each set you find in your language to the pronoun chart.
Tumia eneo hili kwa viwakilishi jumla, yaani viwakilishi ambavyo havirejei au kuwakilisha kitu au mtu maalumu.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a person?

ExampleWords.AUni: person, who, someone, anyone, everyone, no one, each one, whoever

Question.AUni: (2) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a thing?

ExampleWords.AUni: thing, what, something, anything, everything, nothing, each thing, whatever, whichever

Question.AUni: (3) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a time?

ExampleWords.AUni: time, period, when, sometime, anytime, every time, never, at no time, each time, whenever, sometimes

Question.AUni: (4) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a place?

ExampleWords.AUni: place, where, somewhere, anywhere, everywhere, nowhere, each place, wherever, which way

Question.AUni: (5) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a reason?

ExampleWords.AUni: reason, why, for what reason, for some reason, for any reason, for each and every reason, for no reason, why ever

Question.AUni: (6) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a manner?

ExampleWords.AUni: manner, means, how, somehow, anyhow, every way, no way, each way, however

Question.AUni: (7) What pronouns express indefinite reference of an amount?

ExampleWords.AUni: amount, how much, however many, however much, plenty

AStr.Run: Use this domain for pronouns used in relative clauses.
Tumia eneo hili kwa viwakilishi rejeshi, yaani viwakilishi ambavyo huweza kutumiwa kupatanisha kishazi (au kirai) kinachojirejea na kukivumisha kikundi nomino hicho.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used in relative clauses?

AStr.Run: I'm looking for the man <who> killed John.; I found the coin <that> I lost.; That is the reason <why> I did it.
Use this domain for pronouns used in questions.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used in questions?

ExampleWords.AUni: who, what, when, where, how, why

AStr.Run: <Who> is that?; <Where> did you go?; <How many> did you get?; <How often> will you go?; <Why> did you do that?
Use this domain for demonstrative pronouns.
Tumia eneo hili kwa viwakilishi onyeshi, yaani viwakilishi ambavye uamilifu wake ni uonyeshi.

Question.AUni: (1) What pronouns are used to indicate a particular referent?

ExampleWords.AUni: a, an, the, this, these, that, those, specific,

AStr.Run: <the> leader; <a> really old man; <this> new shirt; <these> tomatoes; <that> book; <those> flowers; I want <this>.; <That> is what I want.
Use this domain for words that indicate that someone does something himself, rather than through someone else.

Question.AUni: (1) What words are used to indicate that you do something yourself, rather than through someone else?

AStr.Run: You don't need to do anything. I will take care of it <personally>.; Instead of sending a representative, he is coming <in person>.; You can talk to him <direct>.

Question.AUni: (2) What words are used to indicate that you make something yourself rather than using a machine?

AStr.Run: We made this book entirely <by hand>, using locally available materials.
Use this domain to list all prepositions and postpositions.

Question.AUni: (1) What prepositions are in your language?

ExampleWords.AUni: in, on, at, from, to, away, toward, about,

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all phrase level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two words within a phrase.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two words within a phrase?

ExampleWords.AUni: and, both...and, or, either...or, neither...nor, but,

AStr.Run: coming <and> going; me <and> you; men <and> women; <both> this <and> that; <either> good <or> bad; <neither> good <nor> bad; quickly <but> not carelessly
Use this domain to list all clause level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two clauses.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two clauses?

ExampleWords.AUni: and, or, while, then, if, because,

AStr.Run: You come here <and> I'll go there.; You come here <or> I'll go there.; You come here <while> I go there.; You come here <then> I'll go there.; <If> you come here, I'll go there.
Use this domain to list all sentence level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two sentences.

Question.AUni: (1) What conjunctions join two sentences?

AStr.Run: I want you to come here. <Then> I'll go there.; You wanted to come here. <So> I decided to let you.

AStr.Run: Use this domain to list all derivational affixes. A derivational affix is joined to a root and changes it into a different word. Derivational affixes often change the root into a different part of speech. Adding a derivational affix usually changes the meaning of the root in a significant way.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that intensify an attribute.

Question.AUni: (1) What words intensify an attribute?

ExampleWords.AUni: very, really, highly, deeply, real, so, mighty, one, quite, ever so, bloody, decidedly, too, proper, true, extremely, such

AStr.Run: <very> green; <too> dark; <really> fast; <real> good; <pretty> heavy

Question.AUni: (2) What words intensify an attribute to an extreme degree?

ExampleWords.AUni: extremely, terribly, dreadfully, incredibly, unbelievably, ridiculously, absurdly, remarkably, exceptionally, extraordinarily, terrifically, enormously, hugely, exceedingly,

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that an attribute is not intense?

ExampleWords.AUni: not very, hardly, barely, a little, fairly

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that indicate a degree on a scale.

Question.AUni: (1) What words refer to the degree of something?
(2) What words indicate a degree on a scale?

ExampleWords.AUni: high, low, greater, lesser, first, primary, secondary,

AStr.Run: Ambassador Stevenson is a very <high> level official.; <Low> priority tasks should be placed later in the list.; The musician gave a <first> rate performance.; Finding a suitable place to live was of <primary> importance.

(5) What words express a comparative degree?

ExampleWords.AUni: decline, decrease, diminish, drop, dwindle, fall, plummet, slide, tumble,

(3) What words refer to causing something to become smaller in degree?
(4) What words indicate that something is smaller than another thing in degree?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is done to a complete degree?

ExampleWords.AUni: completely, fully, totally, entirely, wholly, absolutely, utterly, positively, in every way, in every respect, in every sense, through and through, whole-heartedly, altogether, out-and-out, outright, perfect, perfectly, roundly, solid, solidly, thoroughly, unmitigated, unqualified, utter,

Question.AUni: (2) What general words refer to all of something's attributes or manners?
(3) What words describe something that is done completely?

ExampleWords.AUni: complete, thorough, full, comprehensive, exhaustive, entire,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is done partly?

ExampleWords.AUni: partly, partially, to some extent, to a certain extent, to a degree, to some degree, up to a point, in part, sort of,

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something is done one part at a time?

ExampleWords.AUni: gradually, in stages, step by step, one step at a time, in increments, incrementally, piecemeal, by degrees, little by little,

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that modify an attribute.

Question.AUni: (1) What words modify an attribute?

AStr.Run: <light> blue, <dark> red, <dull> gray, <faded> colors
Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that modify verbs.
Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense and aspect.

Tumia eneo hili kwa maneno madogomadogo yanayoonyesha wakati wa kitenzi au hali yake, yaani kipengele cha kisarufi kinachotumika katika vitenzi ili kuonyesha muda au kipindi maalumu ambamo tendo lilifanyika.

Use this domain for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense (also known as temporal deixis)--the time of a situation (event, activity, or state) in relation to a reference point, which is usually the time of utterance. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) present: the situation occurs simultaneously with the moment of speech.
(2) past: the situation occurred before the moment of speech.
(3) future: the situation takes place after the moment of speech; the speaker predicts that the situation in the proposition will hold.
(4) crastinal: tomorrow.
(5) hesternal: yesterday.
(6) hodiernal: today, normally with past.
(7) pre-hodiernal: before today.
(8) post-crastinal: after tomorrow.
(9) ancient past: used for narrating events in ancient or mythical time.
(10) remote: combines with other tense labels to indicate a situation occurring temporally distant from the moment of speech.
(11) immediate: a meaning label that may be combined with other tense labels to indicate a situation not simultaneous with the moment of speech, but very close to it.
(12) immediate future: what is about to occur.
(13) immediate past: occurring immediately before the moment of speech. Also called the Recent Past. Do not use this label if there is any sense of current relevance--use anterior for that.
(14) Immediate may also be combined with anterior or imperative.
(15) expected future: the situation is to occur in the near future; what is scheduled to happen.
(16) narrative time: the use of a form with no other past uses for reporting a past narrative.

(17) gnomic present: the situation described in the proposition is generic; the predicate has held, holds, and will hold for the class of entities named by the subject, such as 'Elephants have trunks'.
(18) What general words refer to the tense of an event?
(19) What words are used to indicate the present tense?
(20) What words are used to indicate the past tense?

ExampleWords.AUni: -ed, (in English vowel replacement is also used to indicate past tense, e.g. run, ran)

Question.AUni: (21) What words are used to indicate the future tense?

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of dynamic verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) habitual: the situation is customary or usual, repeated on different occasion over a period of time. English 'used to' is past habitual; English 'Nancy sings' is present habitual.

(2) continuous: a single situation is viewed as in progress, as maintained over a period of time; also called "durative." The English "Progressive" is a continuous restricted to dynamic words. English 'I am reading; *I am knowing the number'.
(3) continuative: keep on doing what is being done. Restricted to dynamic words.

(4) progressive: the action takes place simultaneously with the moment of reference, 'to be in the process of...'. This is more restricted than the English Progressive, which may be used for events that are not actually in progress at reference time: 'I am writing a book' may be used even if the speaker is not at that moment writing.
(5) excessive duration: action is extended over a long period of time, longer than normal for that action.
(6) limited duration: action performed for a relatively short or bounded period of time.
(7) iterative: the action is repeated on one occasion; usually restricted to dynamic words, often further restricted to semelfactive words.
(8) frequentative: action occurs frequently, not necessarily habitually, nor necessarily on one occasion, as is the iterative.
(9) imperfective: the situation is viewed as unbounded in the sense that it is habitual, continuous, progressive, or iterative.
(10) perfective: the situation is viewed as bounded temporally. It cannot be simultaneous with the moment of speech; in the non-past it is sometimes interpreted as future.
(11) completive: to do something thoroughly and to completion, e.g. 'to shoot someone dead, to eat up'.
(12) inceptive: the action or event begins. We are distinguishing this from the beginning of a state.
(13) delimited: action is performed only a little.
(14) The preceding terms or "Aspects" are not usually relevant to stative words.
(15) What general words refer to an aspect of an event?
(16) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?

ExampleWords.AUni: begin, start, commence, beginning, the start, commencement, initiate, to institute, inception

Question.AUni: (17) What do people say when they want someone else to start?

ExampleWords.AUni: go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go"

Question.AUni: (18) What is a person called who starts something?
(19) What words are used to indicate that someone is attempting to do something?
(20) What words are used to indicate that something is being done quickly?
(21) What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly?
(22) What words are used to indicate something is continuing?
(23) What words are used to indicate that something has been completed?

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of stative verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) state exists: the state is begun before reference time and continues after reference time.

(2) state commences: beginning of a state of "becoming." Often called Inceptive or Inchoative. If there is a morpheme specifically for this meaning, it is usually derivational and restricted to stative words. However, it is also possible for "Perfects" or "Perfectives" to have this as their use with stative words.
(3) state ends: state existed in the past, but no longer exists. Also a possible meaning of "Perfects" or "Perfectives" in combination with stative words.
(4) state continues: state is continuing a reference time.
(5) state changes: (self-explanatory).

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate relational tenses. Relational tenses describe situations where the reference time is not the same as the moment of speech. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) resulting state (resultative): action in the past produces a state that persists into the present.
(2) anterior continuing: past action continues into the present: 'I have waited over an hour' ( = and I'm still waiting).

(3) anterior: the situation occurs prior to reference time, and is relevant to the situation at reference time. This is different from a simple past or perfective, where the situation is reported for its own sake and independent of its relevance to any other situation.
(4) A form that signals a situation that is prior to and relevant to a past reference time will be coded with two meaning labels, past and anterior.

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate agent-oriented modalities. Agent-oriented modalities describe internal or external conditions on a willful agent with respect to the completion of the predicate situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) ability: the agent of the verb has the mental or physical ability to complete the action of the main verb.
(2) ability, mental: English: 'Melissa can speak Dutch'.
(3) ability, physical: English: 'Hortense can swim the English Channel'.

(4) attempt: the agent attempts to complete the action specified by the predicate. Note: this has a sense of incompleteness, and I have seen authors call this "Incomplete" and gloss the examples with 'try'.
(5) desire: the agent of the verb desires or wants to complete the action of the verb.
(6) obligation: the agent is obliged to perform the action of the verb.
(7) obligation, strong: it is absolutely incumbent upon the agent to complete the action of the main verb: 'I have to mail this letter today'.
(8) obligation, weak: it is recommended that the agent complete the action of the main verb: 'Harry ought to get a haircut before meeting Sue's mother'.
(9) permission: the agent is allowed to complete the action of the main verb: 'The students may check books out for two weeks'.
(10) root possibility: it is possible for the agent to carry out the action of the main verb; i.e. s/he is able and external conditions allow it: 'You can get that kind of paper at Ulbrich's'.
(11) intention: the agent intends to carry out the action of the main verb: 'Sam's gonna take Sanskrit next semester'.

(12) andative: agent moves away from the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be going to do something'. Of course such forms are often related to the verb 'to go' and also may have uses of intention and future.
(13) venitive: the agent moves toward the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be coming to do something'. This may be related to the verb 'to come' and may have future uses as well.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words indicating that someone can do something.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that someone is able to do something?

ExampleWords.AUni: can, know how to, be able to, have the ability to, capable,

AStr.Run: John <can> drive a car.; John <knows how> to drive a car.

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to the ability of someone to do something?
(3) What words indicate that someone is not able to do something?

Question.AUni: (2) What words refer to a person's inability to do a job?
(2) Maneno gani hutaja ukosefu wa uwezo wa mtu wa kufanya kazi?

ExampleWords.AUni: incapacity, incompetence, inability, deficiency, lack of training

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something must happen.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that something is necessary?

ExampleWords.AUni: must, need to, have to, have got to

Question.AUni: (2) What words describe something that is necessary?

ExampleWords.AUni: necessary, compulsory, essential, imperative, indispensable, inevitable, mandatory, obligatory, required, unavoidable, urgent, vital,

Question.AUni: (3) What words refer to something that is necessary?
(4) What words describe something that is not necessary?

ExampleWords.AUni: unnecessary, extraneous, incidental, inessential, needless, nonessential, uncalled-for, unessential, unnecessary, unneeded,

AStr.Run: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate moods.

Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate imperatives. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press. Use this domain for words and affixes that a speaker uses to indicate that he is making a command. English has no command word. Some languages change the form of the verb by adding an affix. Some languages have special verbs that are only or normally used as commands. Those verbs could be classified here.
Tumia eneo hili kwa aina ya tungo au maneno yenye kuonyesha amri, ombi, pendekezo n.k..

Question.AUni: (1) imperative: the verb form used for direct commands in the 2nd person. If there are also 1st and 3rd person forms, the meaning can still be that of imperative, with the 1st and 3rd persons being interpreted as 'Let us, let him...', etc.
(2) optative: the proposition represents the speaker's will. Translated into English as 'May you prosper', 'May we all meet again.' with counterfactual: 'If only he had...', etc.
(3) hortative: the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(4) prohibitive: the mood for expressing negative commands. The English is 'Don't'.
(5) admonitive: the command constitutes a warning: 'you had better not...'.
(6) Meanings co-occurring with imperative:
(7) polite: a mild or polite form of command.
(8) delayed: the action of the command is to be carried out in the future rather than immediately.
(9) immediate: the action of the command is to be carried out immediately.
(10) strong: (self-explanatory).
(11) What words indicate that the sentence is a command?
(12) What affixes indicate that the sentence is a command?

ExampleWords.AUni: (none in English), (in many Bantu languages) -e 'a verbal suffix indicating that the sentence is a command'

Question.AUni: (13) What words are only used in the imperative?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for ways of saying that someone should do something. If I say someone should do something, I think it is good that he does it.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.

ExampleWords.AUni: urge, request, let, why don't, please

AStr.Run: I <urge> you to help.; I <request> that you help.; <Let> us all do our part.; <Why don't> you do something to help?; <Please> do something to help.

Question.AUni: (2) What words indicate that something should be done?

ExampleWords.AUni: should, ought to, be responsible for, be duty bound,

AStr.Run: We <should> do something to help.; We <ought to> do something to help.; <Should>n't we do something to help?; This building <should> be torn down.

Question.AUni: (3) What words indicate that something should not be done?

ExampleWords.AUni: should not, ought not to, caution

AStr.Run: We <should not> do anything to hinder them.; We <ought not to> do anything that might harm them.; I <caution> you not to interfere.

Question.AUni: (4) What words refer to something a person should do?
(5) What words describe the person who should do something?
(6) What words describe someone who does what he should?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he is asking a question. English has no question word, but other languages such as Japanese do.

Question.AUni: (1) What words indicate that the sentence is a question?

ExampleWords.AUni: (Japanese) ka? 'a particle coming at the end of a sentence to indicate that it is a question'

Question.AUni: (2) English has an interjection that is added to a statement that has the effect of questioning something about it.

AStr.Run: So, you are going, <hmm?>

Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate epistemic moods. Epistemic moods have the whole proposition in their scope and indicate the degree of commitment of the speaker to the truth or future truth of the proposition. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

Question.AUni: (1) possibility: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is possibly true. Some markers with this meaning also indicate future time: 'He may arrive late because of the weather; It may snow again tomorrow; She could have already taken it'.

(2) probability: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is probably true. Some marker with this meaning also indicate future time. This is sometimes called the "Dubitative" in grammars: 'Paula should be home by now'.
(3) inferred certainty: the speaker infers from evidence that the proposition is true: 'They must have killed a bear here (I can see blood on the snow)'.
(4) certainty: the speaker is emphasizing that the proposition is true.
(5) uncertainty: the speaker is emphasizing that s/he doesn't know that the proposition is true.
(6) indicative: main clause mood that also appears in questions. Contrasts with subjunctive, conditional, and imperative.

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is certainly true or is certain to happen.
